awd_titl_txt: WORKSHOP: Doctoral Consortium at ACM DIS 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This is funding to support 10 of 14 promising doctoral students who will take part in a two-day doctoral research consortium (workshop) that will be held as part of the 2023 ACM SIGCHI Conference on Designing Interactive Systems (DIS 2023). The conference will be held in Pittsburgh July 10-14 with the doctoral consortium taking place July 10th & 11th.  The annual Designing Interactive Systems (DIS) conference, sponsored by the Association for Computing Machinery’s Special Interest Group on Computer Human Interaction (ACM SIGCHI), is the premier international forum where approximately 350 interdisciplinary HCI researchers and practitioners from around the world come together each year to debate and shape the future of interactive systems design. Research contributions are peer-reviewed and widely cited.

The ACM DIS Doctoral Consortium is an important forum to help strengthen and advance diverse contributions to scholarship and practice from young and emerging researchers from a range of backgrounds. Students selected to participate in the event will have the opportunity to present, discuss and receive feedback on their research with a panel of five senior, internationally recognized, and distinguished researchers. They will be able to take part in the entire conference, will present a poster of their work, and will interact with an international audience of interdisciplinary researchers and industry professionals in HCI, design research, and interactive systems.  The 2023 event will be the first opportunity for an in-person and in-situ workshop since 2019.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This funding provided partial support for ten promising graduate students in the Associated Computing Machinery Designing Interactive Systems (ACM DIS) Doctoral Research Consortium, along with three Doctoral Consortium chairs, six faculty mentors, and one keynote speaker. The funding supported nine of the doctoral students directly. 


The two-day doctoral consortium workshop took place on the 10th and 11th of July 2023, and was held in conjunction with the ACM 2023 Conference on Designing Interactive Systems (DIS 2023). DIS 2023’s main conference program was held on July 12-14th 2023 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and was sponsored by the Association for Computing Machinery's Special Interest Group on Human-Computer Interaction (SIGCHI). The Designing Interactive Systems (DIS) conference is the premier international arena where interdisciplinary researchers and practitioners come together to debate and shape the future of interactive systems design. Research contributions are peer-reviewed and widely cited. Over 450 individuals (hybrid and online) attended the conference in 2023. More information about the conference is available online at https://dis2023.acm.org/.

The Doctoral Consortium at DIS 2023 was a two-day research-focused meeting of a group of highly promising PhD students supported by a group of distinguished, international research faculty. The Doctoral Consortium has taken place at DIS since 2002 (the conference was biannual until 2016, when it became annual). Vital to fostering doctoral candidates, it was one of the few forums of the DIS conference that was retained in the shift to online conference programming in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. The 2023 Doctoral Consortium was the first opportunity for an in-person and in-situ workshop since 2019. 


The Doctoral Consortium at DIS offers PhD students in the fields of HCI and design research feedback and mentorship at a key juncture in their professional development by: building practical skills in communicating research to diverse stakeholders; offering feedback on their research; building  professional connections to peers and senior mentors; and build students’ awareness of career paths in computing research across the academy and industry. Applications were encouraged from doctoral students with research interest relevant to the conference, to design research and to human computer interaction, regardless of the fields in which they are earning their degrees.

The consortium took place over two days preceding the main technical program of  the ACM Designing Interactive Systems (DIS) 2023 conference. The consortium was designed, organized and facilitated consistent with previous DIS doctoral consortium workshops.  A diverse cohort of 10 students attended the doctoral consortium. Of the ten participants, four were from US institutions, two from Canadian universities, one from Australia, and three from Europe. One participant was male-identifying and the remainder were female-identifying or other gender identities. No more than two students were from any given institution.

Over the two days, students were each given a 30-minute time-slot to present their doctoral research agenda and receive feedback from faculty mentors.  Student presentations were organized into thematic groups: Human & AI Interaction (3 students); Health & Wellbeing (4 students); and Human & Nature Interaction (3 students). During each session, invited faculty mentors (6 total, 1-2 per presentation group) along with the doctoral consortium chairs provided feedback on the presentations. Student attendees also had a series of supportive sessions where they could gain broader forms of feedback and mentorship including faculty panels and a keynote talk. Following the DC, each student presented a poster on their doctoral work in a session during the main conference.  This was provided as a formal opportunity for student participants to gain additional feedback from the broader ACM DIS community and to provide networking opportunities to support the professional development and career progression of these promising students. Students’ research  was also published as an extended abstract contribution in the ACM DIS 2023 Extended Abstracts and these are available online in the ACM Digital Library. The DIS Conference Chairs evaluated the doctoral research consortium and the results have been made available to the organizers of future DIS conferences and DIS doctoral symposia.
